citations.narrative:
-Animal care staff took part in collecting bear cubs from dens in the larger bear enclosure. The bear cubs are pulled from
the larger enclosure each year for the safety of the cubs and to allow for early preventive veterinary care and treatment. A
facility representative in the inspection said that on a very limited basis in the past fireworks had been used at the entry of
dens (not directed at animals) to get mother bears out and away from the dens and safely retrieve the cubs.
The use of fireworks in this manner can cause trauma, behavioral stress, physical harm or unnecessary discomfort to the
bears. The facility representative said that fireworks will no longer be used to get animals out of their den.
**Ensure corrective actions are taken and maintained.
-The facility representative confirmed that in a video in the press, animal care staff had been recorded suggesting
handling the bear cubs in an aggressive and inappropriate manner such as "holding their muzzles," "pinching their
noses," and "kicking or pushing them away" using their foot. The video did show a staff member pushing away and
scruffing bear cubs away to keep them from climbing or grabbing the staff member's leg.
Suggesting to staff to handle bear cubs in this manner can cause trauma, behavioral stress, physical harm or
unnecessary discomfort to the bear cubs.
The facility representative said that they have met with staff prior to this inspection, and animal care staff were advised
that this type of handling of animals is not allowed and additional training is planned for the animal care staff in the near
future.
**Ensure corrective actions are maintained so that handling of animals is done as expeditiously and carefully as possible
in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or
unnecessary discomfort.

On May 5, 2023 a lynx was found outside of the enclosure when the animal care staff arrived in the morning. Changes
were made to the enclosure based on where the staff suspected the lynx may have been able to escape from.
The facility representative confirmed that on June 13, 2023, the second animal care staff to arrive on duty noticed and
reported one of the lynx was missing from the enclosure. The staff initiated their animal escape protocol to try to locate
the lynx. The lynx was found later that evening hiding far under a deck near the snack building. Per the representative, the
facility used their tranquilizer protocol to capture and return it to an enclosure without incident. The facility reports they are
still unsure of how the lynx got out of the primary enclosure.
Enclosures need to be constructed to contain the animals securely. The affected enclosure for the two lynx was not
constructed in a manner to contain the lynxes.
Note: After the second incident (prior to this inspection), the two lynx were moved to a temporary enclosure while a larger
enclosure was being modified to house them. The lynx have since been moved to the larger enclosure that was observed
to be containing the animals securely. The facility does not plan to use the affected enclosure until it can be closely re-
evaluated and to ensure the lynx containment.
**Ensure that corrective actions are maintained.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Director of Operations.
Additional Inspectors:
SCOTT WELCH, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
